html: In this encounter between Isaiah and Hezekiah, we observe the prophet’s far-reaching perspective when compared to the king’s. Isaiah is concerned with all aspects of Jehovah’s covenant people, even far into the future, while Hezekiah sees only the situation immediately at hand. He even calls Isaiah’s dire prediction “good,” implying that he and his people have passed Jehovah’s test of loyalty and others must answer for themselves. He has met his responsibility as king, establishing “peace” and “loyalty” in the land (Isaiah 9:4-7), while the cause of Judah’s exile rests with future generations.
